Moreover, some say:

The three Dharma seals are called the precious seal samÄdhi. All dharmas are without self, all conditioned dharmas are impermanent, and nirvÄá¹‡a is quiescent extinction. These three Dharma seals cannot be violated by any human or heavenly being in accordance with the Dharma.
Entering this samÄdhi, one is able to contemplate all dharmas in three ways. This is called the precious seal.
Moreover, prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is the treasure, and this corresponding samÄdhi is called the seal. This is called the precious seal.
As for the lion's play samÄdhi, when a bodhisattva attains this samÄdhi, he can enter and exit all samÄdhis at will, whether slowly or quickly.
It is like this: when the various beasts are playing, if they see a lion, they all become frightened.
When the lion is playing, it is self-assured and fearless.
Furthermore, when a lion plays, it kills the strong among the beasts and lets go of the weak;
The bodhisattva is also like this. Having attained this samÄdhi, he destroys the strong among the non-Buddhists and delivers those who have faith.
Furthermore, the lion's play is as explained in the first chapter.
When the bodhisattva enters this samÄdhi, the earth shakes in six ways;
Causing the boiling water in all the hells of the worlds in the ten directions to cool down, the blind to see, the deaf to hear, and so forth.
The samÄdhi of the wondrous moon is like the full and pure moon, free from all obscurations, able to dispel the darkness of night;
This samÄdhi is also like this. When the bodhisattva enters this samÄdhi, he is able to remove the darkness of wrong views, ignorance, and obscurations in all dharmas.
The samÄdhi of the moon-bannered appearance is like the banner of a great army general made with a moon-shaped jewel. Seeing this banner, people all follow it;
When the bodhisattva enters this samÄdhi, all dharmas are unobstructed and all follow along.
The samÄdhi of emerging from all dharmas: the bodhisattva attains this samÄdhi and causes all samÄdhis to increase;
it is like timely rain causing the forests and trees to flourish.
The samÄdhi of observing the peak: entering this samÄdhi, one is able to see all samÄdhis;
it is like standing on a mountain peak and seeing all things.
The samÄdhi of the nature of dharmas: the nature of dharmas is immeasurable and non-dual, difficult to grasp;
entering this samÄdhi, one is able to definitely attain its characteristics.
It is like empty space, which no one is able to abide in;
only by attaining the power of spiritual penetrations can one dwell there.
The samÄdhi of the banner-like appearance: entering this samÄdhi, one becomes the most honored among all samÄdhis;
it is like a general who obtains a banner, symbolizing his greatness.
The vajra samÄdhi: it is like a vajra, which nothing can penetrate.
This samÄdhi is also like this. It penetrates all dharmas without obstruction, enabling each samÄdhi to function as it should;
Just as only a diamond can penetrate lapis lazuli, cat's eye, and agate.
The samÄdhi of entering the seal of dharmas is like a person entering a peaceful country. One with a seal can enter, but one without a seal cannot enter.
The bodhisattva who attains this samÄdhi can enter the true nature of all dharmas, namely the emptiness of all dharmas.
The samÄdhi of the king of samÄdhis and the samÄdhi of establishment is like a great king dwelling in the main hall, summoning all the ministers, who all obey his orders.
The bodhisattva who enters the king of samÄdhis emits great light, inviting and summoning the ten directions, all of whom gather;
And he sends out transformed buddhas to go everywhere in the ten directions.
Establishment is like a king dwelling in the main hall, his body and mind at ease, without any fear.

As for the SamÄdhi of Radiating Light, by constantly cultivating the fire-absorption, one gives rise to the power of spiritual penetrations and can emit various colors of light as one wishes, either hot, cold, or neither hot nor cold, according to the preferences of sentient beings.
As for the SamÄdhi of Illuminating All SamÄdhis, there are two kinds of light:
first, the light of form, and second, the light of wisdom.
Abiding in this samÄdhi, one illuminates all samÄdhis, free from wrong views, ignorance, and so forth.
As for the SamÄdhi of Power and Progress, one first attains the five powers such as faith in regard to all dharmas, and then attains the power of mastery in all samÄdhis.
Moreover, although abiding in samÄdhi, one is always able to transform through spiritual penetrations and deliver all sentient beings.
As for the SamÄdhi of Soaring High, when a bodhisattva enters this samÄdhi, all merit and wisdom increase;
the nature of all samÄdhis arises from the mind.
Necessarily entering the eloquence samÄdhi means the samÄdhi that corresponds with the four unobstructed abilities, eloquence, and eloquence.

When a bodhisattva attains this samÄdhi, he completely knows the sequence of sentient beings' languages, as well as the names and titles of scriptures, and is able to discern them without obstruction.
As for the samÄdhi of analyzing names, although all dharmas are empty, one uses names to analyze the meanings of dharmas and enable people to understand.
The samÄdhi of observing directions means observing sentient beings in the ten directions with a mind of loving-kindness, compassion, and impartiality.
Furthermore, direction refers to following the principle and is called attaining the direction.
By the power of this samÄdhi, one attains the principle of all samÄdhis and freely enters and exits without obstruction.
The samÄdhi of dhÄraá¹‡Ä« seal means that one who attains this samÄdhi is able to discern that all samÄdhis have dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s.

The samÄdhi of non-deception means that there are samÄdhis that give rise to love, hatred, ignorance, wrong views, and so forth, but this samÄdhi is completely free from confusion regarding all samÄdhis.
The samÄdhi of subsuming the ocean of dharmas means that just as all rivers return to the ocean, the dharmas of the three vehicles all enter this samÄdhi, and it is the same.
Moreover, all other samÄdhis enter this samÄdhi, just as the four dhyÄnas and four formless concentrations subsume the various liberations and nine sequential samÄdhis, all entering within them.
The samÄdhi of pervading space means that space is immeasurable and boundless;
the power of this samÄdhi is able to completely pervade space;
either sitting in full lotus posture, emitting light, or filling it with sound.
The vajra-wheel samÄdhi means that just as a genuine vajra wheel goes unimpeded wherever it goes;
those who attain this samÄdhi are unimpeded in all dharmas wherever they go.
Furthermore, it is called a wheel because it can discern the divisions and realms of various samÄdhis.
A wheel is a division and realm.
The jewel-cutting samÄdhi is like a jewel that can polish and refine other jewels;
this samÄdhi is also like this, able to remove the defilements of afflictions from various samÄdhis.
The defilements of the five desires are easy to dispel, but the defilements of various samÄdhis are difficult to remove.
The illuminating samÄdhi means that attaining this samÄdhi, one can illuminate all dharmas with ten kinds of wisdom;
it is like the sun rising to illuminate the JambudvÄ«pa, with all matters becoming evident.
The non-seeking samÄdhi means contemplating all dharmas as illusory transformations, and because attachment to the three realms is severed, there is no seeking at all.
The no-abiding samÄdhi is the samÄdhi named no-abiding;
abiding in this samÄdhi, one contemplates all dharmas as impermanent from moment to moment, without any abiding.
The no-mind samÄdhi refers to the concentration of cessation or the concentration of non-perception.
Why is it so?
The Buddha himself explains the reason:
Entering this samÄdhi, all the mind and mental factors do not operate.
The pure light samÄdhi: light is called the light of wisdom, and the defilements are called impurities;
apart from these impurities, wisdom is then pure.
The boundless light samÄdhi: boundless means immeasurable and innumerable.
There are two kinds of light:
first, in order to deliver sentient beings, one emits light from one's body;
second, in order to discern the general and specific characteristics of all dharmas, there is the light of wisdom.
Attaining this samÄdhi, one can illuminate the boundless worlds and boundless dharmas in the ten directions.
The illuminating samÄdhi: within all dharmas, one can illuminate them, like holding a torch in the dark.
The universal illumination samÄdhi: it is like the precious pearl of a wheel-turning sage king, outside the army, each side illuminates a yojana;
the bodhisattva attaining this samÄdhi universally illuminates the various approaches of all dharmas.
The samÄdhi of firm and pure samÄdhis means that because the bodhisattva attains the power of this samÄdhi, he makes all samÄdhis pure and firm.
The samÄdhi of stainless light means the samÄdhi that is in accord with the three gates of liberation;
attaining this samÄdhi, one is free from all defilements of samÄdhi, free from all ignorance and craving, and is also able to illuminate all samÄdhis.
The samÄdhi of joy means that attaining this samÄdhi, one gives rise to joyful bliss towards all dharmas.
What is it?
Some say:
The first dhyÄna is it.
As the Buddha said, there are four cultivations of samÄdhi:
First, cultivating this samÄdhi, one attains present joyful bliss;
Second, cultivating samÄdhi, one attains knowledge and vision, seeing the birth and death of sentient beings;
Third, cultivating samÄdhi, one attains wisdom and discernment;
Fourth, cultivating samÄdhi, one attains the destruction of contaminants.
Furthermore, attaining this samÄdhi, one gives rise to immeasurable and boundless joyful bliss towards the dharmas.
The lightning samÄdhi is like lightning briefly appearing, the practitioner finds the way;
One who attains this samÄdhi, from the beginningless world system, loses the way and regains it.
The inexhaustible samÄdhi is, having attained this samÄdhi, extinguishing the characteristics of impermanence, etc., of all dharmas, and immediately entering non-arising and non-ceasing.
The majestic virtue samÄdhi is, the bodhisattva attaining this samÄdhi, majestic virtue adorns.

The separation from exhaustion samÄdhi is, the bodhisattva attaining this samÄdhi, immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya eons of wholesome roots and merits are necessarily attained, the fruition and recompense not being lost.
The immovable samÄdhi, some say:
The fourth dhyÄna is immovable.

In the desire realm, because of the five desires it moves; in the first dhyÄna, because of initial and sustained thought it moves; in the second dhyÄna, because of much joy it moves; in the third dhyÄna, because of much bliss it moves; in the fourth dhyÄna, being apart from inhalation and exhalation, without any characteristics of movement, it is immovable.
Some say:
The four formless concentrations are immovable, being apart from all forms.
Some say:
The concentration of cessation is immovable, because it is separated from mind and mental factors.
Some say:
Because it is associated with the wisdom that cognizes the true characteristics of all dharmas, which is ultimately empty, it is immovable.
Having attained this concentration, one does not engage in conceptual proliferation regarding any concentration or any dharma.
The concentration of non-regression means that abiding in this concentration, one does not see any regression in the concentrations.
The treatise says:
The bodhisattva abiding in this concentration always does not regress, which is the concentration associated with the wisdom of non-retrogression.
Non-regression means not falling from the peak, as explained in the meaning of not falling from the peak.
The concentration of the sun lamp means that attaining this concentration, one can illuminate the various gates and concentrations of all dharmas;
It is like the sun rising, able to illuminate the entire JambudvÄ«pa.
The concentration of the pure moon means that the moon gradually diminishes from the sixteenth day until the thirtieth day, when it is completely exhausted;
Ordinary people are also like this. Their wholesome merits gradually diminish and are exhausted, and they fall into the three evil destinies.
It is like the moon, which gradually increases from the first day to the fifteenth day, when its light is pure and clear;

Bodhisattvas are also like this. Having attained this samÄdhi, from the time of arousing the mind, their wholesome roots gradually increase in every lifetime, up to attaining the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, receiving predictions, and their wisdom being pure, benefiting sentient beings.
Moreover, they can destroy the ignorance within all samÄdhis.
The Pure Illumination SamÄdhi: Illumination is called wisdom, and defilements are obstructions.
Those who attain this samÄdhi have no obstructions regarding all dharmas;
For this reason, the Buddha explains here:
Abiding in this samÄdhi, one attains the four unobstructed understandings.
Question:
Why does the Buddha alone explain the four unobstructed understandings here?
Answer:
In samÄdhi, there is no mind with discursive thought. What is joyfully spoken is contrary to concentration, and this is difficult!
By the power of this samÄdhi, one attains the four unobstructed understandings.
The meaning of the four unobstructed understandings is as explained above.
The samÄdhi that can create illumination: Illumination is wisdom. Among all wisdoms, prajÃ±Ä wisdom is the foremost.
This samÄdhi associated with prajÃ±Ä can create illumination.
The samÄdhi that creates activity: By attaining this samÄdhi, one can give rise to all previously attained samÄdhis.
The samÄdhi that knows characteristics: By attaining this samÄdhi, one sees the true characteristics of wisdom within all samÄdhis.
The vajra-like samÄdhi: By attaining this samÄdhi, one can penetrate all dharmas with wisdom, yet does not see penetration, because there is nothing to attain.
Question:
Why are all three kinds of samÄdhis called vajra?
Answer:
The first mentions vajra, the middle mentions vajra wheel, and the last mentions like vajra.
Vajra-like samÄdhi - the Buddha said it can penetrate all dharmas, and also does not see this vajra-like samÄdhi able to penetrate all samÄdhis.
Vajra wheel samÄdhi - attaining this samÄdhi, one is then able to uphold the wheel of all samÄdhis.
These are all meanings spoken by the Buddha himself.
The treatise says:
Vajra-like samÄdhi - able to destroy all afflictive hindrances without remainder;
It is like Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra holding a vajra to destroy the asura army.
This is the final thought of a learner, and from this thought one attains the three kinds of enlightenment in sequence;
ÅšrÄvaka enlightenment, pratyekabuddha enlightenment, and the Buddha's unsurpassed enlightenment.
Vajra samÄdhi - able to destroy all dharmas and enter nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder, no longer accepting existence;
It is like a true vajra able to destroy all mountains, leaving no remainder.
As for the adamantine wheel, this samÄdhi can destroy all dharmas, unobstructed and unimpeded;
it is like an adamantine wheel turning, destroying everything without obstruction.

Furthermore, the first is adamantine, the second is an adamantine wheel, and the third is like adamantine; the names are distinguished, and the Buddha's explanation of their meanings is also different;
the treatise author's explanation of their causes and conditions is also different, so one should not raise objections.
As for the samÄdhi of the mind abiding, the characteristics of the mind are light, swift, far-reaching, formless, difficult to control, and difficult to maintain; it is always in a state of movement;
like a monkey, or like a flash of lightning, or like a snake's tongue.
By attaining this samÄdhi, one is able to gather and maintain it;
even heavenly desires cannot cause the mind to waver, let alone human desires!
As for the samÄdhi of universal illumination, by attaining this samÄdhi, one sees the characteristics of light and brightness in all dharmas, without any darkness.
Just as one sees during the day, so it is at night;ğŸ”½...
Just as one sees in front, one sees in the back in the same way;
Just as one sees above, one sees below in the same way, without obstruction in the mind.
By cultivating this samÄdhi, one attains the supernormal power of the divine eye, universally seeing light, clearly and unobstructed.
By skillfully cultivating this supernormal power, one attains the wisdom eye, universally illuminating all dharmas, seeing without obstruction.
As for the samÄdhi of firm establishment, one who attains this samÄdhi is firmly established and stable in all meritorious and wholesome dharmas;
Like Mount Sumeru in the great ocean, firmly established and unmoving.
As for the samÄdhi of a treasure trove, one who attains this samÄdhi has all lands transformed into the seven treasures.
Question:
Is this seen by the physical eye?
Is it seen by the meditative state?
Answer:
Both the divine eye and the physical eye can see.
Why is it so?
Because the external six sense objects are not fixed;
The practitioner constantly cultivates meditative concentration, and therefore can transform the original appearances.
The Samadhi of the Wonderful Dharma Seal: The wonderful dharma refers to the profound merits and wisdom of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas;
Attaining this samadhi, one attains the profound and wonderful merits and wisdom.
The Samadhi of Equality in the Dharma: Equality has two kinds:
Equality of sentient beings and equality of the dharma.
The samadhi that accords with the equality of the dharma is called the equality of the dharma.
The Samadhi of Cutting Off Joy: Attaining this samadhi, contemplating the impermanence, suffering, emptiness, no-self, impurity, etc. of all dharmas, the mind gives rise to revulsion;
Among the ten contemplations, this samadhi corresponds to the contemplation that all worlds are not enjoyable.
The Samadhi of Reaching the Summit of the Dharma: The dharma refers to the bodhisattva dharma, namely the six perfections;
Reaching the perfection of wisdom, attaining the power of skillful means, reaching the summit of the dharma.
Attaining this samadhi, one is able to abide at the summit of this dharma, and the ignorance and afflictions cannot move or shake it.
The SamÄdhi of Dispersal: Attaining this samÄdhi, one can break apart and disperse all phenomena;
It is the SamÄdhi of Dispersal Conjoined with Emptiness.

The SamÄdhi of Distinguishing the Phrases of All Dharmas: Attaining this samÄdhi, one can distinguish all dharmas, their language, words, and phrases, and expound them to sentient beings without any impediment in speech; it is the SamÄdhi of Discerning Speech Conjoined with Delight.
The SamÄdhi of the Equal Characteristics of Letters: Attaining this samÄdhi, one observes that all letters and words are completely equal;
There is no aversion or attachment to scolding or praise.
The SamÄdhi of Transcending Letters: Attaining this samÄdhi, one does not see letters within meaning, nor does one see meaning within letters.

The SamÄdhi of Cutting Off Conditions: Attaining this samÄdhi, whether it be pleasure, one does not give rise to joy; if it be suffering, one does not give rise to anger; if it be neither pleasure nor suffering, one does not give rise to a mind of equanimity.
Far from and unattached to these three feelings, the mind then returns to cessation;
If the mind ceases, then conditions are also cut off.

The indestructible samÄdhi is a samÄdhi that takes the nature of dharmas and ultimate emptiness as its object, which cannot be destroyed by frivolous discourse, cannot be turned by impermanence, because it has already been destroyed.
The seedless samÄdhi is such that when one attains this samÄdhi, one does not see the various characteristics of dharmas, but only sees the one characteristic, namely, the absence of characteristics.
The samÄdhi of non-abiding is such that when one attains this samÄdhi, one knows that the fire of the three poisons burns the three realms, so the mind does not rely on them;
because nirvÄá¹‡a is ultimately empty, one also does not rely on it.
The samÄdhi of leaving obscurity is such that when one attains this samÄdhi, the subtle obscurations and ignorance in all samÄdhis are all completely eliminated.
The samÄdhi of non-going is such that when one attains this samÄdhi, one does not see the coming and going of all dharmas.
The samÄdhi of immutability is such that when one attains this samÄdhi, one observes that all dharmas do not change causes into effects, just as milk does not change into curd;
because all dharmas abide in their own characteristics and do not move.

The samÄdhi of crossing over the six sense objects means that by attaining this samÄdhi, the afflictions within the six sense objects are completely extinguished, one crosses over the great ocean of the six sense objects, and one is also able to transcend the wisdom that arises from the objects of all samÄdhis.

The samÄdhi of accumulating all merits means that by attaining this samÄdhi, one accumulates all merits, from faith to wisdom, practicing without cease throughout the first and last watches of the night;
like the sun and moon traversing the sky, not resting even for a moment.
The samÄdhi of abiding in the absence of thought means that by entering this samÄdhi, one does not follow the mind but only follows wisdom, abiding in the true characteristics of all dharmas.
The samÄdhi of the pure and wondrous flower means that just as a tree blooms with flowers, causing the tree to be adorned;
by attaining this samÄdhi, the flowers of all merits bloom among all samÄdhis, adorning oneself.
The samÄdhi of the mind of enlightenment means that by attaining this samÄdhi, all samÄdhis are transformed into the uncontaminated, corresponding to the seven factors of enlightenment;
It is like a pound of mineral dye that can transform a thousand pounds of copper into gold.
The samÄdhi of immeasurable eloquence is precisely the eloquence of delight.
By attaining the power of this samÄdhi, one can delight in expounding a single phrase for immeasurable eons without exhausting it.
The samÄdhi of the unequaled is such that by attaining this samÄdhi, one views all sentient beings as being like buddhas and views all dharmas as being the same as the Dharma of the buddhas.
It is associated with the prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ of the unequaled.

The samÄdhi of transcending all dharmas is such that by attaining this samÄdhi, one enters the three gates of liberation, transcends the three realms, and delivers the sentient beings of the three vehicles.
The samÄdhi of discerning all dharmas is precisely the samÄdhi associated with discerning wisdom.
By attaining this samÄdhi, one discerns the characteristics of all dharmas as being wholesome or unwholesome, with outflows or without outflows, conditioned or unconditioned, and so forth.
The samÄdhi of dispelling doubts is such that some say:
It is precisely the samÄdhi of signlessness within the path of seeing the truths;
The fetter of doubt is eliminated by the samÄdhi corresponding to the wisdom of seeing the truth.
Some say:
The samÄdhi corresponding to the bodhisattva's acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas is it.
At that time, all doubts and webs within all dharmas are completely severed, one sees the buddhas of the ten directions, and attains the true characteristics of all dharmas.
Some say:
The samÄdhi corresponding to unobstructed liberation is it.
After the buddhas attain this samÄdhi, they have no doubts regarding any dharma, whether near or far, all are like observing them in the palm of the hand.
The samÄdhi of no abode is the samÄdhi corresponding to the wisdom of non-acceptance.
Attaining this samÄdhi, one does not see any dharmas having a definite abode.
The samÄdhi of single adornment: attaining this samÄdhi, one observes all dharmas as one;

Or because all dharmas have characteristics, they are one; or because all dharmas are non-existent, they are one; or because all dharmas are empty, they are one; there are innumerable such ways they are one.
The wisdom of one characteristic adorns this samÄdhi, so it is said to be one adornment.

The samÄdhi of arising and practicing means that practice is called contemplation. Attaining this samÄdhi, one is able to contemplate various aspects of practice, the aspect of entering, the aspect of abiding, and the aspect of emerging;
Moreover, these practices are all empty and cannot be seen.
The samÄdhi of one practice means that this samÄdhi is always in accordance with the characteristic of ultimate emptiness, and there are no other practices in sequence;
For example, in the practice of impermanence, there is next the practice of suffering, and in the practice of suffering, there is next the practice of non-self.
Moreover, the bodhisattva in this samÄdhi does not see this shore, nor does he see the other shore.
The characteristics of entering various samÄdhis are this shore, and the characteristics of emerging are the other shore;
The characteristic of initial attainment is this shore, and the characteristic of cessation is the other shore.
The samÄdhi of not one practice is contrary to the above samÄdhi of one practice, namely, various other contemplative practices.

The samÄdhi of wonderful practice is precisely the samÄdhi corresponding to ultimate emptiness, not seeing even the characteristics of non-duality, and all frivolous arguments being unable to destroy it.
The samÄdhi of penetrating and dispersing the basis of all existence: existence refers to the three realms of existence;
the basis is the state of neither perception nor non-perception, because it is difficult to reach, it is called the basis.

Penetrating means using uncontaminated wisdom to reach the state of neither perception nor non-perception, and enter nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder, where the five aggregates of the three realms are dispersed.
Furthermore, the bodhisattva attains the wisdom of non-arising and non-cessation, and all existences are penetrated and dispersed, all becoming non-existent.

The samÄdhi of entering names and words: attaining this samÄdhi, one understands the names of all sentient beings, all things, and all dharmas, and is also able to use these names and words to teach others;
all languages are fully understood, and all have their sequence.

The samÄdhi of leaving behind sounds and words means that attaining this samÄdhi, one observes that all dharmas are devoid of sounds and language, and are always characterized by quiescent extinction.
The torch-bearing samÄdhi is like holding a torch while walking at night, not falling into danger.
The bodhisattva who attains this samÄdhi uses the torch of wisdom in all dharmas without error or attachment.

The pure appearance samÄdhi means that attaining this samÄdhi, one is able to purify and fully adorn the thirty-two marks, and is also able to observe the general and specific characteristics of all dharmas according to the Dharma. One is also able to observe the pure characteristiclessness of all dharmas, namely emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, as extensively explained in the chapter on characteristics.
The samÄdhi of breaking appearances means that attaining this samÄdhi, one does not see the appearances of any dharmas, let alone the appearances of various samÄdhis!
One attains this signless samÄdhi.

The SamÄdhi of the Perfection of All Kinds of Excellence means that by attaining this samÄdhi, one is endowed with and adorned by all merits, namely, a good family, a good home, a good body, good retinue, and the perfection of pure dhyÄna and wisdom.

The SamÄdhi of Not Rejoicing in Suffering or Pleasure means that by attaining this samÄdhi, one contemplates that worldly pleasure has many faults and many afflictions, is false and inverted, and is not something to be delighted in.
One contemplates that worldly suffering is like an illness, like an arrow piercing the body, and the mind does not delight in it.
Because all dharmas are deceptive, one does not seek pleasure.
Why is this?
Because at another time, it changes into suffering.
If one does not even delight in pleasure, how much less so in suffering!
The SamÄdhi of the Sign of Inexhaustibility means that by attaining this samÄdhi, one contemplates that all dharmas are indestructible and inexhaustible.
Question:
If that is so, then why not fall into the extreme of permanence?
Answer:
Just as the bodhisattva, although contemplating impermanence, does not fall into annihilation,
If contemplation is not exhaustive, one does not fall into eternalism;
these two characteristics cannot be found in any dharmas.
For the sake of practicing with causes and conditions, namely, in order to not lose merit and demerit, it is said to be eternal; in order to be free from attachment, it is said to be impermanent.
The dhÄraá¹‡Ä« samÄdhi means that by attaining the power of this samÄdhi, all dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s such as hearing and retaining are naturally obtained.

The samÄdhi of subsuming all false and correct characteristics means that by attaining this samÄdhi, one does not see the three groups of sentient beings, namely those with correct concentration, those with false concentration, and those with indeterminate concentration, and completely abandons nothing, single-mindedly subsuming them.
Moreover, within all dharmas one does not see the characteristics of definite correctness or definite falsity, because dharmas have no definite characteristics.
The samÄdhi of extinguishing aversion and fondness means that by attaining this samÄdhi, one does not give rise to love in delightful dharmas and does not give rise to aversion in detestable dharmas.
The samÄdhi of going against and following means that by attaining this samÄdhi, one has mastery over going against and following within all dharmas;
It can destroy sentient beings with wrong views and can accord with the minds of sentient beings to be transformed.
Moreover, because of detachment, it destroys all dharmas;
because of the growth of wholesome roots, it accomplishes all dharmas;
it also does not see any dharmas as contrary or in accord, and it does not see this matter either, because it is non-existent.
The samÄdhi of pure light means that attaining this samÄdhi, the defilements of afflictions in all dharmas cannot be obtained;
because they cannot be obtained, all samÄdhis are pure.
As for the firm samÄdhi, some say:
this is the vajra samÄdhi, because it is firm and indestructible.
Some say:
it is not the vajra.
Why is this?
Because the vajra is also easily broken.
